replies.bodyText:
Currently, ODFE plugin has following mode

Completely Disable  --> Security plugin is completely disable
SSL Only. --> Only node to node encryption
Full mode  --> All functionality (including Basic auth, RBAC, DLS/FLS, SAML, LDAP, Multi-tenancy etc.. )

So we should support for NoTLS to TLS path for both above options 2 and 3.
Additionally, we are also testing disabling TLS as configuration option for Full mode. Means ODFE users can configure ODFE clusters with all security features described in option-3 with TLS disabled.  So supporting  Dual mode will help for ODFE community to move their self-managed clusters from TLS Disable to enable without downtime.

replies.bodyText:
We determine the SSL_DUAL_MODE setting value based on a combination of the value from elasticsearch.yml file and corresponding cluster setting value. The object provides access to the value of SSL Dual mode config, which once set can only be modified via the cluster setting. The object is used during the setup of new connections in the transport server and transport client code to check the dual mode setting.
For this use case the class was designed as a singleton since we want to object to be created only once and used multiple times. If class is not singleton we would need to pass the created object to all places it is being used in.

timeline.bodyText: Are we never expecting message less than 6 bytes?  how did we ensure that message will always be 6+ bytes?
timeline.author: hardik-k-shah

replies.bodyText: It is ensured by ES. Minimum payload size for ES transport protocol is 6 bytes. i.e ES Handshake for ex is the most smallest message(6 bytes) that can be sent.
replies.author: vengadanathan-s

replies.bodyText: Can you please point to the code where this is enforced.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/381d7586e4067c1ce0dd840e704b21da9dbeb61b/server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/transport/TcpTransport.java#L103 and https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/381d7586e4067c1ce0dd840e704b21da9dbeb61b/server/src/main/java/org/elasticsearch/transport/TcpTransport.java#L733-L749
replies.author: vengadanathan-s

replies.bodyText: In case the first byte is not 0x16, can't we reliably say that it is not TLS?
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: The first byte wont not be sufficient to reliably conclude that the message was TLS or not, also additionally we need to check the first 6 bytes of the message for the custom dual mode client-server handshake
replies.author: sachetalva

replies.bodyText: In case of TLS should not the first byte be always 0x16? I understand that you can't reliably say that it is TLS and/or dual mode client-server handshake until all 6 bytes are received, but it should be possible to reliably say that it is not using the first byte.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
The first byte can tell that it is not SSL message in some cases, but there may still be scenarios where we would need to check the first 5 bytes to confirm whether a message is SSL or not. The intention was to always prefer SSL connections when possible.
Also, we have a custom handshake message exchange which requires us to send at least 6 bytes of data between the transport client and transport server. This custom handshake helps in keeping the connection setup / probe deterministic and quick.
Moreover, the entire logic to check the first 6 bytes only applies during the EIT migration phase (i.e. when dual mode is enabled)
Once the flag is disabled, the DualModeSSLHandler code is never used.
replies.author: sachetalva

replies.author: vengadanathan-s

replies.bodyText:
It may be enabled by accident in which case ES should terminate with a reasonable error message and not be stuck  waiting for a response that will never come.
Additionally, it looks that the handshake may require establishing 2 extra socket connections (one long lived connection and 2 short lived socket connections). Why one connection is not sufficient?
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
I have updated the error message to be more clearer.
Regarding the 2 extra sockets, we will be opening only 1 extra socket in the best case, i.e. if transport server supports dual mode. And 2 sockets when transport server does not support SSL.
The short lived connections are required to probe the transport server to check if it supports SSL connection.
Also, these extra sockets are opened only when dual mode is enabled (i.e. during EIT migration phase), in all other scenarios this part of code is never hit.
The following scenarios are possible:

Dual mode is enabled; Transport client and transport server both support dual mode:

Transport client opens a socket to perform a custom handshake with the transport server
Transport server responds to custom handshake and closes the socket (since this is a plain text socket and cant be used any more)
Transport client now knows that the server supports SSL and proceeds with SSL connection (full SSL Handshake will take place)


Dual mode is enabled; Transport client supports dual mode, transport server does not support dual mode and dual mode is enabled:

Transport client opens a socket to perform custom handshake with transport server.
Transport server does not recognize this message and closes the connection.
Transport client see that connection is closed and opens another socket to send ES Ping
Transport server responds to this ES ping.
Transport client will proceed with plain text connection with this transport server.


Dual mode is disabled:

No extra sockets are opened, SSL connections are setup by default.

replies.bodyText: ODFE supports not only TLSv1.3, it is necessary to support other versions that openssl and Java supports.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
My bad, updated the comment, we ignore only SSLV2 and it is not technically a TLS protocol, from SSLv3 onwards it is made as TLS, to be backward compatible TLS version header continued to use major version of SSL i.e 3 and minor version to specify the version of TLS.
major+minor version of TLS versions:
TLS1_VERSION           x'0301' # major version 3, minor version 1
TLS1_1_VERSION         x'0302' # major version 3, minor version 2
TLS1_2_VERSION         x'0303' # major version 3, minor version 3
Check that we currently do: https://github.com/vengadanathan-s/opendistro-security/blob/master/src/main/java/com/amazon/opendistroforelasticsearch/security/ssl/util/SSLUtil.java#L51-L66 , where we major version is 3 i.e TLS message or not. AFAIK It should not true for all TLS versions, but it wont detect SSLv2 (deprecated long and no longer used anywhere) .
